title: Functional phenotyping of hepatic lymphocytes in murine MASH by mass cytometry
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Harvest of mouse liver
Timing: 10 min per mouse
This procedure describes liver perfusion and harvesting liver from mice. This protocol is validated for non-diseased and MASH livers.
Clean the hood and prepare for perfusion by filling 10 mL syringes with PBS and 1 mL syringes for cardiac puncture.
Euthanize mice following the institutional Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals.
Expose the peritoneal and thoracic cavities.
Perform cardiac puncture through the right ventricle with a 1 mL syringe to remove circulatory immune cells.
Inject 5 mL of PBS into the left ventricle, ensuring the liver inflates. Snip the portal vein and look for bleeding, then perfuse another 5 mL into the heart. The liver should turn less red.
Harvest the liver from the mouse in one piece.
Note: Remove the gall bladder (located under the right lobe). Cut connective tissue to facilitate the removal of the liver in one piece.
Weigh the liver and place it in a labeled 50 mL tube with 10 mL of RPMI on ice.
Repeat steps 2–7 for each mouse.
Critical: Perfuse slowly to achieve homogeneous perfusion of the liver. If using CO2 for euthanasia, do not leave mice for too long in the CO2 chamber to avoid blood clots interfering with the perfusion.
Preparation of single-cell suspension
Timing: 2.5 h
This step describes how to isolate a single-cell suspension of intrahepatic lymphocytes, MOMFs, monocytes, and neutrophils from a mouse liver.
Transfer the liver in 10 mL RPMI to a gentleMACS C-tube. Homogenize the liver using a gentleMACS dissociator (Program: C.O1, 0 TUBE).
Transfer the homogenate to a 50 mL conical tube, and add RPMI up to 50 mL.

Centrifuge at 60 × g for 1 min at a temperature between 20 and 25°C with no brake.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]
Transfer the supernatant to a new 50 mL tube. The resulting pellet contains unwanted debris, be careful not to dislodge it.
Centrifuge the supernatant at 480 × g for 8 min at a temperature between 20 and 25°C with brake.
Prepare a 37.5% Percoll solution:
Mix 3.75 mL of Percoll with 6.25 mL of HBSS (without Ca2+ and Mg2+) to make a 10 mL solution for each sample.
Aspirate and discard the supernatant, resuspend the pellet in 10 mL of 37.5% Percoll, and transfer to a 15 mL conical tube.
Centrifuge at 850 × g for 30 min with no brake at a temperature between 20 and 25°C (may take between 45 min and 1 h to stop).
Aspirate the supernatant leaving the pellet intact. Prepare a 1X red blood cell (RBC) lysis buffer by diluting 10X RBC lysis buffer with DI water.
Add 5 mL of 1X RBC Lysis buffer and incubate on ice with occasional shaking for 5 min.
Add 10 mL of RPMI media supplemented with 10% FBS to neutralize the lysis buffer. Centrifuge to pellet (300 × g for 5 min at 4°C).
Aspirate the supernatant. Repeat the wash with 5 mL of PBS. Centrifuge to pellet (300 × g for 5 min at 4°C).
Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL of Maxpar PBS (PBS free of contaminating metals).
Count the cells and determine viability using preferred methods.
Transfer the desired cell number (typically 1 × 106–3 × 106 cells) to labeled flow cytometry tubes. Centrifuge to pellet (300 × g for 5 min at 4°C).
Cell surface staining for CyTOF
Timing: 2.5 h

This step describes how to stain for cell surface antigens in single-cell suspensions of intrahepatic lymphocytes for CyTOF data acquisition using metal-conjugated antibodies.
Stain the cells with cisplatin to discriminate between live and dead cells. Prepare a 0.5 μM cisplatin solution from a 1 mM stock solution by diluting in Maxpar PBS.
Resuspend the cells in 500 μL of 0.5 μM cisplatin solution and mix well.
Incubate at a temperature between 20 and 25°C for 5 min.
Critical: Do not incubate for more than 10 minutes to avoid over-staining which can lead to a difficult distinction between live and dead cell staining.
Quench the staining with 4 mL of the Maxpar cell staining buffer.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant.
Repeat steps 27–29 for a second wash.
Resuspend the cells in 50 μL of Maxpar cell staining buffer containing 1 μg of Fc receptor blocker.
Incubate at a temperature between 20 and 25°C for 10 min.
Prepare the antibody master mix by adding the pre-titrated amounts of antibodies and Maxpar cell staining buffer for a final volume of 50 μL per sample. Prepare sufficient master mix for n+2 samples.
Add 50 μL of the master mix to each sample and mix thoroughly by vortexing.
Incubate for 15 min at a temperature between 20 and 25°C.
Vortex and repeat incubation for another 15 min at a temperature between 20 and 25°C.
Add 2 mL of the Maxpar cell staining buffer to samples and centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant and repeat wash with 2 mL Maxpar cell staining buffer. Centrifuge and discard supernatant.
Prepare 1.6% methanol-free formaldehyde by diluting the 16% stock with Maxpar PBS.

Critical: Disrupt the cell pellet by vortexing samples before adding formaldehyde solution to avoid clumping of cells.
Add 1 mL of 1.6% formaldehyde solution to samples and vortex gently to mix.
Incubate at a temperature between 20 and 25°C for 10 min.
Centrifuge at 800 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Critical: Centrifuge speeds need to be increased after fixation to achieve greater cell recovery
Aspirate supernatant.
Prepare a 31.25 nM Cell-ID intercalation solution by diluting the stock 125 μM solution in Maxpar fix and perm solution.
Add 1 mL of the 31.25 nM intercalation solution to each sample. Mix gently and incubate for 1 h at a temperature between 20 and 25°C if acquiring the sample the same day or store at 4°C.
Note: Cells can be stored at 4°C for up to 48 hours before sample acquisition
Prepare the Cells for Acquisition.
Centrifuge the tubes containing the cells in the intercalation solution at 800 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Aspirate the supernatant.
Add 2 mL of the Maxpar cell staining buffer to the cells.
Centrifuge cells at 800 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Aspirate the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 1 mL of DI H2O. Mix thoroughly and use 10 μL of the cell suspension to determine a cell count.
Centrifuge the cells at 800 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant.
Cytoplasmic/secreted antigen staining for CyTOF
Timing: 1.5 h
These steps are optional and describe how to stain for cytoplasmic and secreted antigens such as cytokines in single-cell suspensions. After completing steps 24–38 from the cell surface staining procedure above, proceed to step 52 below.
Prepare a 1X Fix I solution from the 5X stock solution by diluting it with Maxpar PBS.

Critical: Disrupt the cell pellet by vortexing samples before adding fix I solution to avoid clumping of cells with fixation.
Add 1 mL of 1X Fix I solution to the cells and vortex gently to mix.
Incubate at a temperature between 20 and 25°C for 20 min.
Wash cells with 2 mL of Maxpar Perm-S buffer.
Centrifuge cells at 800 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Aspirate the supernatant.
Repeat the wash and centrifugation.
Make the antibody master mix by adding the pre-titrated amounts of antibodies and Maxpar Perm-S buffer making up the volume to 50 μL per sample.
Note: Prepare sufficient master mix for n+2 samples.
Add 50 μL of master mix to each sample and mix thoroughly by vortexing.
Incubate for 30 min at a temperature between 20 and 25°C.
Wash and fix the samples following steps 37–51 from the cell surface staining procedure.
Sample acquisition by CyTOF
Timing: 30 min per sample
These steps describe how to acquire samples on a CyTOF2 instrument (DVS Sciences).
Note: Ensure that the CyTOF2 system is appropriately warmed up, tuned successfully, and ready to begin acquiring the sample before proceeding.
Note: Cells should be processed on the same day that they are washed free of the intercalation solution.
Create an experiment template assigning metal channels to their corresponding antibodies.
Wash each loop with HPLC-grade water.
Prepare a 0.1X EQ bead solution by making a 1:10 dilution with HPLC-grade water.
Run a bead sensitivity test by injecting 500 μL of diluted EQ bead solution followed by acquisition on the CyTOF2 instrument. Gate out singlets and assess the results.
Note: If the mean in the 151 Eu and 153 Eu channels is ≥ 1000 events, the instrument passes the bead sensitivity test and is ready to acquire samples.

Using the previously determined cell counts, adjust the cell concentration in diluted EQ bead solution to achieve 5.0 × 105 cells/mL.
Note: Resuspend cells right before acquiring the samples.
Filter the resuspended cells through a 35 μm filter cap propylene tube.
Inject 500 μL of cell suspension to sample loop 1 and run for 1200 s at a 0.045 mL/min introduction rate.
Inject another 500 μL of cell suspension into sample loop 2 when prompted.
Wash both sample loops with 500 μL of HPLC-grade water after the acquisition is completed for each sample.
Repeat for all samples.
Inject sample loops with washing solution and run for 10 min.
Inject sample loops with HPLC-grade water and run for 10 min.
Turn off the plasma.
Remove the nebulizer and soak it in 10% Contrad-100 in DI H2O followed by HPLC-grade water.
Use the CyTOF Software with default FCS Processing settings to normalize the final FCS files.
